titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Hunter Reynolds Papers and Collection
1980-20007 (Bulk 1993-2007)
MSS 319
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Laura Newsome and Colin Torre.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-10-16T15:03-0400

did.abstract: The Hunter Reynolds Papers and Collection comprise consists of source material, photographs, videotapes, sketches, press, and correspondence created and received by visual and performance artist and AIDS activist Hunter Reynolds. The processed portion of the collection is material related to Reynolds' Memorial Dress Project, which commemorates individual victims of the AIDS pandemic.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Hunter Reynolds Papers and Collection are subdivided into series organized by project and media-type.

The Memorial Dress and Book project (Series I, Subseries A and B) collects the material related to Reynolds' Memorial Dress project; it is arranged in alphabetical order between 4 boxes of printed material, 3 objects, and 1 oversized container. Series II includes the test fabrics for the Memorial Dress and the Memorial Dress. Oversize Series I includes two poster tubes containing the Memorial Dress plastic name templates.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Hunter Reynolds is a visual and performance artist and AIDS activist. An early member of ACT UP, in 1989 Reynolds co-founded Art Positive, an affinity group of ACT-UP to fight homophobia and censorship in the arts. Reynolds' performance, photography, and installations address his experience as an HIV-positive gay man living in the age of AIDS; the work speaks to issues of gender identity, political, social, and sexual histories, mourning and loss, survival, hope and healing. Among his projects are Patina du Preyâ€™s Memorial Dress, The Drag Pose Series, Blood Spot Series and Mummification Series. He has collaborated on major performance projects including The Banquet with Chrysanne Stathacos and I-Dea The Goddess with Maxine Heneryson.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: The bulk of this collection remains unprocessed and is not represented in this finding aid.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Series I and associated objects in Series II are open to researchers. The rest of the collection is unprocessed. Appointments are necessary for the use of manuscript and archival collections.
Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date (if known); Hunter Reynolds Papers and Collection; MSS 319; box number; folder number; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University Libraries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Hunter Reynolds Papers and Collection consists of source material, photographs, videotapes, sketches, artworks, press, and correspondence created and received by artist and AIDS activist Hunter Reynolds. The processed portion of the collection is material related to Reynolds' Memorial Dress Project, which commemorates individual victims of the AIDS pandemic.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: The collection was acquired by NYU's Fales Library & Special Collections from Hunter Reynolds in June 2011.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Series is divided into two subseries, documenting the production phase and the exhibition phase of the dress and its accompanying materials. Folders are arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Series I documents Hunter Reynolds' Memorial Dress project, spanning the years 1992-2010. The series includes material related to the construction and exhibition of his Memorial Dress -- a black ball gown silk-screened with the names of 25,000 people who died of AIDS. Exhibitions of the dress were modeled by Reynolds in character as his alter ego, Patina du Prey. The Memorial Dress was premiered in 1992 at the ICA of Boston, was presented during the 25th anniversary of the Stonewall riots, and produced in collaboration with The Contemporary Art Institute of New York. The material documents the conception and exhibition of the Memorial Dress in the U.S. and internationally, and includes press, production material, exhibition files, and the dress itself.
